description: 1974 Alfa Romeo GTV
Solid California car on actual mileage title
Ground up build from a true Alfa enthusiast
Amazing custom leather interior
Striking and desirbale LeMans Blue exterior
2.0L horizontally opposed 4 cylinder engine with dual Webers
5-speed manual transmission
4 wheel disc brakes
Air conditioning

MotoeXotica Classic Cars is pleased to present this unique and rarely seen 1974 Alfa Romeo GTV. This 1974 Alfa Romeo GTV full custom is a true one-of-a-kind ride, built by a longtime Alfa enthusiast from the ground up in 2010 with only about five hundred miles on the clock since then! Second only to the Spider, they are probably the most recognizable of the production Alfas. This is a customized GTV Alfa and not for everyone, but if you want to stand out from the crowd at the next “Cars and Coffee”, you've found your baby!

The Alfa Romeo 2000 GTV Bertone Coupé, was as ground breaking work for Bertone and it is still regarded as one of the prettiest Coupés ever produced. His design had a stunning visual balance, that was enhanced by the clever use of shaping to the front and rear screens. GTA's had the performance to match the looks, and they saw remarkable success in the Trans-Am Series and in the touring car scene in Europe as they carried the torch for Alfa Romeo in the '60s and '70s.

Finished in a LeMans Blue (European color), this coupe shows extremely well with only minor imperfections visible upon close inspection. The body has GTA door handles and locks. GTV 1750 (instead of 2000's) tail lights and front grille.  The front and rear bumpers fit is extremely tight and finish is exquisite. The weather-stripping is pliable, with little or no signs of drying, tearing or shrinkage. The car has a slight window tinting that compliments and completes the “sport” appearance. The 15-inch Panasport's make this one of a kind Alfa look awesome!

Inside, a full-custom Edelman saddle leather “Corbeau” sport seats with red stitching, The custom door panels and dashboard are made from the same leather as the seats designed to mirror the cabin and compliment the sporty exterior of the car. Roll Bar painted to match exterior and padded. White face “Classic Instruments” back lit gauges ergonomically placed, function as originally designed. Custom “Alfaholics” billet clutch, brake and accelerator pedals. The Red Luisi 3 spoke steering wheel displays well with no real signs of wear. Kenwood navigation, display has a back up camera, GPS, Bluetooth and iphone hookup.  Seven Sony Explode speakers (with sub woofer) within a custom saddle leather enclosure that replaces the rear seat seats all look great with no major signs of wear visible. Battery jumper posts in a  matching custom leather trunk.

This Alfa is equipped with a rebuilt, 158hp dual Weber DCOE 40's, 2.0L 4-cylinder engine,  heat wrapped custom race header, “Alfaholics” stainless steel exhaust system wrapped in Titanium wrap, close ratio 5-speed manual transmission, “Alfaholics” limited-slip rear differential, 4-wheel disc brakes. It is equipped with a “Alfaholics”  aluminum fuel cell with foam and remote fill. Upgraded to 15-inch polished Panasport alloys with Potenzas radials on all four corners.

This GTV is very enjoyable to drive short or long distance, whether highway or better yet twisty back roads. This GTV is the affordable way to take you back to when these Alfa's dominated sports car racing… GET OUT AND DRIVE!!!
Current mileage on the odometer shows 982, it is sold as is on a clean & actual mileage California title.

title: 1978 Alfa Romeo Sprint Sprint Veloce Coupe 44000 Miles

description: 1978 Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce – Only 44,000 Original Miles. Updates, Great Driving Alfa!
Highlights:

Great driving, low mileage Alfa coupe. Upgraded induction system and many sensible performance and visual upgrades High end customs wheels and quality tires. Very Reliable - Drive it Anywhere.
$8,950 Trades Welcome
Mileage:  44,000 Original Miles!
Color:  Ivory Mostly original Paint
Engine:  Weber Carbed Engine..Original FI and other Parts Included in sale
Trans:  5 spd
Options:  Many
Condition:  Original with some rust in front cowl, bottom or doors and rear valence/license plate panel.

In 1974, the car was introduced under the name Alfa Romeo Alfetta GT. However, after six years it has changed its name and design. Alfa Romeo GTV 2.0 received larger bumpers andwheels, less chrome and a stronger, two-litre engine. The bonnet line was kept as beautiful and timeless as before and all that was designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro at Italdesign. This car can also impress by its technical side - rear-wheel drive, transaxle, brakes that are mounted by differential to reduce unsprung weight, high double wishbone at the front and de Dion axle at the back - Alfa Romeo GTV 2.0 is full of interesting features, that will satisfy not only the driving enthusiast but also the car design lover.This lot can be viewed and picked up in Gdansk, Poland.

1979 Alfa Romeo Spider Veloc
e with spica fuel injection, 5-speed manual transmission, and convertible top. Rides in the mountains are great! Engine rebuilt a couple of years ago.

Offered in a fantastic condition: an icon from the 1960s, an Alfa Giulia 1300 TI that is truly in mint condition. According to many it is THE original Giulia, the nicest ever built with the perfect interior.The sight of the special odometer, the original dark red interior, the wonderful shifting five-speed gearbox, the super sound of the 1300cc Alfa engine, everything makes driving in this cult Alfa a real pleasure.During the 1960s, this was a revolutionary car that was far ahead of its time......The car has a Dutch registration number and has a Dutch Periodic Vehicle Inspection, valid until March 2019.Until 2015 the car was used in Italy (Milan) and comes complete with the full history. The car was entirely restored with original NOS parts, gearbox, engine and drivetrain, checked by Usato, the eminent Alfa specialist in Ridderkerk, the Netherlands, the brakes have been completely taken apart and reassembled to mint condition.This car doesn’t need anything and is ready to be used for the next 50 years.This Alfa can be viewed and picked up in Fijnaart, the Netherlands.

title: 1967 Alfa Romeo Giulia Sprint GT Veloce

description: Chassis  AR247703
Engine AR0035612922
Incredibly Well Preserved California Car With Original Interior
Exceptional Example With Original Sheet Metal and Chrome
Comprehensive Major Servicing Recently Completed

Despite its ups and downs as company, to a true car enthusiast, its hard to deny the appeal of the Alfa Romeo name. One may bring up the many years where Alfa strayed from its roots after being bought out by Fiat and was building cars that were lack luster to say the least. However, one cannot forget the many years where Alfa Romeo was Alfa Romeo, producing dominant racing cars and some of the most gorgeous road cars in automotive history. Enzo Ferrari himself, got his start as a racing driver for Alfa which inspired him to build the Ferrari brand we know today. They have the racing pedigree, beautiful Italian styling, engines that seem to rev for an eternity, and chassis that make driving a true pleasure.

In 1963, Alfa introduced the Giulia Sprint GT, designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro. The design features of the Giulia were unlike anything the car world had seen before in a road car. The overall shape heavily emulated the 2000 GT and 2600 GT while being perfectly portioned between the overall dimensions as well as the ratio of glass and metal. It was simplistically perfect. In 1966 the platform saw slight revisions with the introduction of the Giulia Sprint GT Veloce, receiving a 1600cc engine to replace the previous 1300cc power plant. Additional alternations included a revised front grille, the now iconic 4-clover badge on the C-pillar, new bucket style seats, and wood look insert on the dash face. It essentially maintained all the design elements of its predecessor but had more horsepower and torque.

The example on offer is a 1967 Alfa Romeo Giulia Sprint GT Veloce, chassis number AR247703, engine number AR0053612922. With 69,000 original miles, one-respray in its factory assigned red color, matching numbers 1600cc engine and pristine original interior, this step-nose is an extremely rare and correct example. The history of this car begins on March 8, 1967 with its date of manufacture. It was sold one week later; March, 17, to Alfa Romeo Inc., in Newark. Aside from that item, there is little else known about the early history of this example. An email correspondence between two of the prior owners, Chris Billings and Donald Schwartzkopf, notes this example being under the ownership of a Mr. Dave Rugh in Vancouver, Washington from the early 1980's to about 1998. Beginning in 2010, we see that the car was being registered to a Mr. Lauber Martin of Mill Valley, California. According to Mr. Schwartzkopf, this Alfa spent the majority of its life in California. Given the car's superb condition, lack of rust, and supporting documentation, it is quite possible that it very well did. This example has now made its way to the east coast, currently for sale out of the LBI Stable in Philadelphia.

The previous owner also claims this step-nose was resprayed in the late 1980's which currently shows beautifully. There is a lack of overspray, even in the typical areas, with the overall finish having aged well. The red paint still possesses a nice shine and is free of any deep scratching. Inspecting the front end closely, one will notice some minor stone chips and light specking from road use but nothing severe enough that would require refinishing. All the metal is believed to be original to the car. One may notice a few very shallow dings in the body when observed at the correct angle, again nothing serious but worth noting. This Giulia has fantastic panel fitment, displaying to indications of even being damaged or modified.

The glass appears to be original, the factory cold start and information stickers still on the front windshield, a convincing element of overall originality. All of the chrome shows nicely with no pitting, dents, or notable scratches having been incurred. The rubber components are free of any dry rot or damage, remaining supple and presenting well. The factory steel wheels have been refinished at some point with the correct “Fergat” stickers on each. The polished hubcaps do have some blemishes such as a light scuff, dulling of the finish, and clouding of the circular black insert.

The interior of this Alfa Romeo is a real gem as it has been preserved in its factory finishes. Even the paint on the door jams is believed to be original. The Black Skai leather bucket seats, appearing more so gray than black, are in great shape and lack any tears or significant side bolster wear. The rear seats show just as well, most likely having been rarely used given their condition. Inspecting the leather dash, no pulling has developed nor significant fading from sunlight exposure. The imitation wood dash insert presents without any issues, as well as all of the gauge faces. Both door panels, headliner, and floor mats are free of significant faults. The red rugs have developed some mild discoloration and a portion has torn at the edge of the driver side foot well. While the tear is noticeable, it would not be worth sacrificing the originality by replacing the rugs. Given the small nature of the blemishing, they should be left as is for the time being. The remaining interior components and trim pieces are correct and are near flawless.

Open up the bonnet and one is greeted with a factory correct engine bay, that shows to be very tidy and well sorted. The believed to be matching 1600cc power plant possesses the correct intake components, twin Weber carburetors, and green spark plug wires. The serial number stamping is clearly visible on the firewall as well as the chassis number tag. Some finishes are not as crisp as they once were, having developed a patina over the years. The rear trunk shows to be very correct and well-kept much like the rest of the car, with the spare wheel and jack present. An inspection of the undercarriage will yield few discrepancies. The frame is structurally sound, suspension components have been gone through, floor pans and rocker panels are clean and rust free, and there is no undercoating present. It should be noted that the oil pan has been slightly damaged from bottoming out at some point which is a common occurrence among Alfas of the era. Aside from that minor item, all else seems to be in order.

Since 2013, this Giulia Sprint GT Veloce has received over $15,000 in receipts which outlines the tending to of every mechanical system to ensure that this example is completely sound in every aspect. Below are some of the major items that were addressed:
All suspension components removed and refinished
All fluids flushed, replaced, and bled
Rear differential assembly installed
KONI red shock absorbers installed in front and rear
Parking brake cable replaced
All calipers and brake pads replaced
Fuel tank removed, reconditioned, recoated, and resealed
Tie rod ends replaced
Sway bar link bushings replaced
Right front wheel hub removed and packed with fresh grease
Correct shift knob installed
Exhaust replaced

All of these service items were executed by the specialists at Radcliffe Motor Car Co. of Reistertown, Maryland. This Alfa reliably starts from cold with a pull of the choke lever and turn of the key. Once warm, the car runs flawlessly with the 1600cc power plant preforming wonderfully and without issue. The sorting of the suspension makes the car extremely composed in the turns, supplying just enough roll to remind you that you are driving a classic sports car. The clutch operates without fault and the lovely 5-speed gearbox shifts in and out of gear seamlessly. The braking system has been gone through in full and performs as such, allowing the user confidence when in need to promptly knock off speed. The steering has no excess play, feeling very tight, and accurate through turns. During use, engine temperature and oil pressure remain consistent, never dropping or exceeding normal levels.

This Alfa Romeo step-nose is an honest example that reminds us what Alfas are all about. Unmodified and mechanically sorted, this Giulia Sprint GT Veloce is a rarity among its kind, as it is truly challenging to find examples in comparable condition to this one. Its original interior furthers its desirability and makes for an opportunity that is hard to pass up on for any Alfa Romeo enthusiast. Offered with the sale are the books, tools, jack, and Coco mats.
Please visit www.LBILimited.com for many more photos and detailed information. Worldwide shipping is available upon request. Follow us on Instagram and Facebook @LBILimited claimyourclassic.

The car was entirely restored with original NOS parts, gearbox, engine and drivetrain, checked by Usato, the eminent Alfa specialist in Ridderkerk, the Netherlands, the brakes have been completely taken apart and reassembled to mint condition.This car doesn’t need anything and is ready to be used for the next 50 years.This Alfa can be viewed and picked up in Fijnaart, the Netherlands.
1966 Alfa Romeo Duetto Spider. Same owner for the last 44 years or so. Car is originally from Nashville, bought at Madison Smith Naturally; it has the cast dealer logo on the back.

Body is in very good condition. The passenger footwell around the jacking point was rusty when I got it, so I fiberglassed that area. Very minor rust in driver's footwell, no rust anywhere else. The paint job is 30+ years old, there are a 30-year accumulation of dings, and the car definitely needs repainting to look its best.

Engine is a fresh 1750 that's been in the car about five years, rebuilt by me, with less than 5,000 miles on it. Original Weber 40DCOE27 carbs. Clutch was new at that time. I sourced a carbureted front cover from Australia so the engine doesn't have an unused fuel injection pump mount on the front. If you don't tell anybody, they would never know it's been upgraded - until you put your foot in it. Much more torque than the original engine. I will include a complete 1600 engine if you want it: it's not the correct S/N for this model, but it is the engine I had in the car for many years.

Other upgrades include: 2-liter rear end with limited slip and 4.10 axle ratio; lightweight 1300 flywheel; Pertronix electronic ignition; ATE brakes all around with ceramic pads for no dusting; Panasport Racing 15x6 wheels; Spax shocks; later-style shifter housing with one-piece shift lever; rear swaybar, very recent BFG performance tires.
Top has shrunk a little so it is quite tight but in good shape, Rear window is clear.

Interior: new seat upholstery last year, and I had the original seat patterns duplicated exactly. (This is a very early Duetto with several detail differences from the later production cars.) Dash pad was replaced 10-15 years ago and is perfect. There's a Stewart-Warner oil pressure gauge installed, since I have never been able to find the correct sending unit for the original Jaeger gauge. Carpet installed probably 30 years ago, still in nice condition.

Spares include: original 4.5 x 15” steel wheels wheels in good condition; '69 trunklid with no rust; extra set of trunklid torsion bars; original transmission parts to go back to the two-piece shifter if you want; grille; original oil pressure gauge; an original 155-15 Pirelli Cinturato tire for spare duty (there's one in the car, too); some other parts that will undoubtedly surface when I start looking.

I have used this car the way an Alfa was meant to be used. I autocrossed it extensively when it was new to me, and was very successful until the four-valve, mid-engine Toyota MR2 came into my class. I also drove it multiple times in the Walter Mitty Challenge at Road Atlanta. It probably saw a thousand miles on the Road Atlanta track. I have several trophies from those days, too.
All suspension components have been replaced (some several times) over my decades of ownership. As far as I know, it needs nothing mechanically now.

Lots of details are non-original on this car; I set it up for maximum performance and enjoyment. However, if you wanted to put it back to original condition, you could do that very easily. I added a 3rd brake light to keep people from getting too close to the boattail; easily removed if you want to delete it.
Never wrecked. Drives perfect, runs damn near perfect and very strong, gearbox good. This car would be a perfect basis for a full restoration, or you could drive it as I have for another forty years!
